question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I understand the importance of deep data, specifically when it comes to understanding the experience of a group of people. Big data is the law of the land right now, but deep data provides a different type of insight that allows us to understand why and how decisions or behaviors come about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to listen better. That may sound very simple but it honestly is so true. I've left this class able to prioritize listening to others and truly take note of what they've said.
Additionally, I've learned how to better ask questions and to recognize that sometimes questions will lead you in different directions from where you started, just like life, and that's ok.
I've learned to prioritize the process as much as the outcome because I've learned so much just in my first semester and have ended up in places I didn't necessarily expect I would've at first.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Makhulu really prioritized discussion, as well as conversation. By making our classes more informal at times, it allowed for deeper conversation. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course is a perfect blueprint to writing an ethnography, and not only that, but study its core components, why its relevant in todays anthropology field, and where it can be applied in everyday/worldly scenarios. This course taught several skills sets, research related, finding the right methods for you / your project, and helpful writing tips, not just for ethnographies but research related in general (very helpful for a senior thesis).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was different than all the other anthropology courses. Instead of just learning about a topic or learning about anthropology you get to actually do it! I learned how to operate in the field as well as conduct interviews. This skills are valuable beyond anthropological research because it teaches you to be able to enter a space and be curious about it and how to interact to with those in it to learn more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that giving us plenty of time to work on this semester-long project allowed us to really dig deep and learn anthropological methods through experience. I liked the structure of the class, with helpful readings in the beginning and then time to work on and discuss our projects, and the workshops were particularly helpful. Not only is it good to get commentary on my work, but it was also helpful to read other people's work to see how they were structuring or going about things.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I would keep...
1. the writing of an entire ethnography over the semester (really helps to turn concepts into things that are tried)
2. spending some class days doing work together (really forced me to revise certain aspects)
3. having sporadic assignments due (I liked being forced to use concepts I wouldn't have otherwise)
4. individual professor feedback

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Design Thinking Process: Learned the structured phases of design thinking, including customer empathizing, opportunity definition, and solution ideation. Gained practical experience conducting stakeholder interviews and mapping value chains, which deepened the understanding of user-centered design.
Triple Bottom Line Analysis: Developed skills in evaluating business opportunities for their environmental, social, and economic impacts. This insight emphasized the importance of sustainability in innovation.
Entrepreneurship and Business Modeling: Acquired knowledge about creating business models, conducting market research, and pitching climate-tech ideas. This hands-on approach built confidence in entrepreneurial thinking and decision-making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The main tangible I developed during this course is how to navigate "tough" entrepreneurial situations within the context of a team. 
(1) Communication skills - the ability to share, critique, and build upon others' ideas
(2) Discerning value from conversations - the ability to have a conversation with someone who may only tangentially relate to your project, but connect their expertise to the overarching mission of your project
(3) Storytelling - how to get someone to care about what you are doing, the "why" aspect of a startup

response_text: Design Climate is a hands-on, interdisciplinary course where you’ll tackle real-world climate challenges through design thinking and collaboration with industry professionals. response_text: Design Climate I focuses on understanding the market, interviewing stakeholders, and conducting SWOT analyses, all of which are essential for any business. If you're only interested in building cool technical devices, this class may not be the best fit for you. However, if you want to create something meaningful from scratch—designing a product that addresses a user's pain point—then this is the perfect class for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are no design elements in this course. It is a marketing/entrepreneurship course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: - A crash course/simulation of developing a product, but not reflective of how things work in the "real world" or what it takes to develop a successful product; it will, however, give people a rough sense of the basics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are wondering "what content will be taught to me in this course" the answer is entrepreneurship 101. If you are looking to learn about a specific clean technology, whether it be related to renewable energy, infrastructure adaptation, sustainable materials, or sustainable business, it will not be taught to you. Further if you would like to apply engineering design, mechanical/electrical/chemical/computer engineering concepts, or any other area of academia, you will have to seek it out yourself. These realities, however, do reflect the real world. Just know what to expect.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While the course teaches you a lot of things in a short time, and helps you learn new skills, it is a lot of work. We are students at the end of the day, so we are juggling many other things besides this course. Be mindful of the time commitment and only take this course when your other work is less intense. Or if you are extremely passionate about one of the projects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Design Thinking Process: Learned the structured phases of design thinking, including customer empathizing, opportunity definition, and solution ideation. Gained practical experience conducting stakeholder interviews and mapping value chains, which deepened the understanding of user-centered design.
Triple Bottom Line Analysis: Developed skills in evaluating business opportunities for their environmental, social, and economic impacts. This insight emphasized the importance of sustainability in innovation.
Entrepreneurship and Business Modeling: Acquired knowledge about creating business models, conducting market research, and pitching climate-tech ideas. This hands-on approach built confidence in entrepreneurial thinking and decision-making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct stakeholder interviews, how to pivot from idea to idea, and the difficult roadblocks that inevitably occur when turning a business into a reality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many skills in entrepreneurship such as: how to conduct market research/market segmentation, how to conduct empathy interviews to understand stakeholder perspectives, and how design thinking can strengthen the process of trying to upscale a startup.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Technology developments that Duke and its partners are working on, as well as the climate technology ecosystem in Durham/NC.
- "Lean startup"-esque methods, such as beachhead markets and SWOT analysis
- Technical understanding of the climate challenge we tackled.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The main tangible I developed during this course is how to navigate "tough" entrepreneurial situations within the context of a team. 
(1) Communication skills - the ability to share, critique, and build upon others' ideas
(2) Discerning value from conversations - the ability to have a conversation with someone who may only tangentially relate to your project, but connect their expertise to the overarching mission of your project
(3) Storytelling - how to get someone to care about what you are doing, the "why" aspect of a startup

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Understanding the process of converting idea into product. 
Creating a startup doesn't necessarily mean that innovator may have all the information and that it's okay
Market analysis and research

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the nature of group work, and I think it would be beneficial to keep group work as this class moves forward.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is an experiential learning course in that the goal of the course is to try to build out a climate tech startup. I felt sometimes the course structure(assignments, quizes, etc.) got in the way of the true goal. Intstructors were more focused on assignments and assessing the work we did than working WITH teams to guide and help development. I think there should be more collaboration going on between groups and instructors.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I very much enjoyed the design thinking workshop by the external consultant. I wish the class was more strongly informed by design thinking methodology rather than disciplined entrepreneurship.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the structure of the course because the assignments were all relevant to our learning for the course and for our advancing our potential business. I think we should have had lectures that focused more on how to conduct stakeholder interviews and providing a better structure prior to giving us the client list.

Constant support from instructors

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
- I think this class could have given students more room, time, and space to innovate and problem solve on their own and in a less set-in-stone time frame
- It might be more suitable for undergraduates or those very early in their careers.  For anyone who has had some professional experience, it can feel pretty stifling or taking a step back in terms of professional seriousness or rigor.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
What made this class stimulating:
The real-world feel of the class was something I had been craving out of school my whole life. You can't look up the answers to this class on Chegg! You have to look in the real world! This was incredibly an incredibly stimulating aspect.How could it be more intellectually stimulating:
More team building / alignment exercises / time-spent agreeing on what the project will look like. To be fair, this may be the fault of our Team Charter. However, I believe that that assignment could have been so much more than filling out the Team Charter template that the professors provided. We didn't realy talk about a way to come up with ideas and build them out. We didn't talk about how we were going to implement science and engineering into the course's assignments. If we had, there would have been more opportunity for intellectual stimulation.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Many assignments, especially those part of the business wayfinder, helped me think in new ways and challenge my assumptions. They were intellectually stimulating. However, they could've been better with some more time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of this class was dynamic, inclusive, and deeply engaging. Professors Gelfand and Henschel cultivated a space where theory and practice met in meaningful ways. The combination of seminar-style discussions, creative media assignments (One Minute videos, Zine workshop), and collaborative final projects allowed for a multifaceted learning experience that accommodated a wide range of learning styles.For future years, I would strongly recommend keeping the combination of theory-based readings, digital production, and the reflective essay as core pillars of the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Conversational skills -- We were asked to sit with a new table of people every week. Many of the activities included some sort of group work or sharing, so I got to know my classmates well.
Self reflection -- Most of the exercises included a reflection aspect, whether it be listing takeaways on a paper assignment or sharing how we felt with others verbally.
Creative thinking -- We were given a lot of creative freedom, and innovative problem-solving / design thinking is something that was encouraged. For example, we were allowed to format and fill out the Life Story poster in any way that made sense to us.

This class forced me to think as an entrepreneur and consider so many different factors that go into business like cost, team members, the idea, timing, market competition, and more. I got much more confident and comfortable with public speaking too, which I was not expecting to be one of my greatest and most valuable takeaways from this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of subtle, overlooked concepts. Creative placemaking, the interplay of public/private/non-profit institutions, and this is the biggest thing: a greater appreciation of arts institutions & events around me. Before this class, I really didn't look to go to museums or art exhibits or dance performances. However, my positive experiences with these aforementioned things have motivated me to go to more events around campus and Durham. I think this is most notable with the performances in Page Auditorium. I will also say this course has helped me network/ reach out when working with my community partner. This was especially relevant when I wanted to include an extra component in the project and I had to gather the resources/data from different teams in the organization and outside.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

This is very dependent on the people in the class, though. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is probably the most impactful class I have taken at Duke because I learned and experienced so much. We were put into group projects to help with a specific arts organization, where we gained so much insight on what it is like to help with arts administration as well as policy. We also went on multiple class excursions that allowed us to understand how the audience interacts with the art institutions, as well as our experience with it. Everything in this course- especially the content- was so meaningful and important for me to learn about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The biggest stimulating factor were the fieldtrips & the semester long project. They were more dynamic and allowed us to incorporate a lot of skills we personally had. It gave us an organization or community to reach out to, which helped. I think tying the fieldtrips back to the concepts we learned was enlightening. This was most seen in the writing assignments, such as the discussion posts. There was a lot of critical thinking and realization that "oh yeah, this particular institution shows a concept we highlighted in class" or "I did not even realize this institution probably had to mull over their economics & that this affected their policy." I think the final paper was kind of shoved in there at the end, but I much prefer that over any final exam.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed a more nuanced and open mindset toward failure as a necessary and even valuable part of growth both personally and professionally. Three specific things I learned were:
 I learned how to reinterpret failure not as a setback, but as a meaningful part of the creative and innovation process. The course helped me understand that failure is often where the most valuable insights come from.
 I developed skills in personal reflection through writing and discussion which allowed me to better process my experiences and view them through emotional and intellectual lenses.
 The course encouraged me to step outside of my comfort zone and take creative and intellectual risks without fear of being "wrong." That shift in thinking was incredibly freeing and helped me grow more confident in uncertain situations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think socially, how to research/investigate before jumping straight to solutions and how to socially adapt in innovation. This course has truly shown me that we all have the capability to socially innovate, but it’s the strategy used in how we go about innovating. Standing by your morals and not being afraid to fail will stick with me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the biggest takeaways from this class is how I learned that in social innovation, you have to stay true to your values to create impact and change. Social innovation is not a well-trodden path, and yet needs to be propose a implement an innovation that is better than any existing ones: and with that, doubts and taking risks may seem daunting. But knowing what you're passionate about and "falling in love" with the problem at hand, can facilitate thinking into action, whether that be in problem analysis, team building, impact gap analysis, etc. Additionally, I learned that Social Innovation (in deriving traits from Human centered Design) puts people at the center of the problem, and hence, with that in mind, it means that a social innovator needs to cater towards the users' habits. And furthermore, when these two aspects of passion and putting people at the center merge, considerations for theory of change, iterating of your solution, and communicating to investors and other people to create a 'team' can follow; however, I also learned that money is a significant factor into creating an sustainable organization that can create impact long-term --> impact investing!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to create an impact gap canvas, a problem tree root analysis, and what social innovation is and how does it work along the three sectors individually and interchangeably.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I absolutely love Dr. Clements. He cares so much about his students as people, and he is great at grounding us in the reality of right now. I really appreciate his check-ins at the beginning of every class, and the way that he tries to get to know specific things about each of us and then check in on those things throughout the semester. I loved the guest speakers, and I also thought that the Theory of Change paper was a very important exercise for us to go through. I also really appreciated the individual attention he gave to each project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Clements gives his students ample time to work in groups and brainstorm different ways to confront dominant issues in global health. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor did an amazing job making the class a comfortable environment where I felt like I could share my ideas without judgment. It was not a stressful experience and I feel like it helped me get over some of my fears of presentational speaking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked how we investigated global health in the real world. I think a lot of times global health is presented as a set of statistics which are definitely important to know and understand, but it is equally as important to be able to find solutions to these problems. As such, I enjoyed that the project was to design a solution to an actual global health problem. It felt applicable and real. That being said, there were a couple class periods that felt a bit slow. I wish a few more discussion-based classes happened, similar to the discussion we had on Project M.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I liked the guest speakers a lot. I think it would have been more stimulating if the structure of class varied a little more, instead of just switching between guest speakers and group work days. It would have been cool to do some more case studies or other activities for us to think and discuss as a class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the aspect of having a big pitch and presenting it at the end of the semester of a panel of judges makes the class extremely stimulating and enjoyably challenging.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It would also be nice to have more class-wide discussions about speakers.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We had individual projects as well as a thoughtful group project where we needed to develop a concept and carry it through till the presentation we had to give to investors.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class consists of a semester-long group project to design an innovation that mitigates a global health problem your group identifies. Most class periods are spent doing research and designing your innovation with your group. Dr. Clements also brings in interesting guest speakers to talk about their experience designing innovations in global health, and you write a short reflection piece after each guest lecture (graded for completion). It is an easy, interesting class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is an interesting, project-based course that will get you thinking in new ways. Most work is completed during class time, and you work in groups for the entire semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

This class is a great I&E and global health class to take! Dr. Clements is one of the best professors you will get the honor or learning from.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of foundational information about the importance of feminism in both real life and the digital space, the prevalence of sexism in Silicon Valley, and various online spaces perpetuating sexist narratives. I also improved my ability to listen, take in new perspectives, and use video editing software to get my visions and ideas across.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the increasing role of AI in the technology industry, the bro culture in tech, and how to use Premiere Pro.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned and became extremely proficient in Adobe Premire.
I also was able to synthesize social theory with contemporary tech issues
I developed a way of thinking of seeing technology not as neutral, but shaped by and reinforcing power structures (race, gender, class, ability).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more broadly about media and how it relates and shapes the world of feminism. I learned a lot more about the tech industry and the gender discrimination that has taken place over the years, especially in Silicon Valley. I lastly learned how to use interfaces such as Premier Pro to become more comfortable with video making and editing, which will be very helpful in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Henschel and Gelfand were always available for extra help with our video projects and writing. Additionally, they both made sure our external readings and documentary studies were relevant to the course and facilitated intellectually stimulating discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The one minute videos on Premiere Pro, the final project, and the forum posts all encouraged my engagement with the course. I would keep the one minute videos and the final project. I also loved group work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of this class was dynamic, inclusive, and deeply engaging. Professors Gelfand and Henschel cultivated a space where theory and practice met in meaningful ways. The combination of seminar-style discussions, creative media assignments (One Minute videos, Zine workshop), and collaborative final projects allowed for a multifaceted learning experience that accommodated a wide range of learning styles.For future years, I would strongly recommend keeping the combination of theory-based readings, digital production, and the reflective essay as core pillars of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors really encouraged group based discussion more and more as the course progressed and I think this was one of the strongest components of the course. It allowed for the sharing of opinions, and ideas on the readings/videos that we were assigned and also allowed for conversations relating to more personal application experiences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professors offered a lot of help and guidance and made it clear they were always there to support us if we needed help with an assignment. The specific workshop days in CDS really helped me develop my skills as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about the customer- customer empathy. How to design a product- find the pain points and provide a solution. How to prototype and wireframe first on paper, then with figma. How to raise capital for a venture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the process of ideation of design thinking and focusing on a human-centered problem-solving. Moreover, I learned how to effectively build prototypes to run tests on customers and evolve the solution in an efficient and fast pacing way. Lastly, I learned about how to get investments for early stage startups and understand the main concepts of finances within the startups' world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I enjoyed talking to the speakers who had real-world experience.

response_text: I learned the steps of design thinking, how to finance a venture, and how to create a prototype for a product.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Design thinking, communication, negotiation, funding insights

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- We started off by learning about the ideation process. Specifically learned about different methods of brainstorming and selecting an idea to our client's problem

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned all about very sectors in the media, tech, art, and entertainment industries-- learning about roles in sports, gaming, news, digital art, immersive experiences, and more. We had classes focused on different job functions-- from venture capital 101 to marketing to creative partnerships. A big focus of the course was the introduction of AI into these fields as well as the importance of the creator and attention economies. I learned about the digital art collecting and creation space, the genius behind Liquid Death's marketing campaigns, and why Netflix's real competitors are gaming companies-- we are all fighting for customers' attention.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The briefs were very challenging in my opinion but helped us stay engaged because they was no way to fake them. I thought the blasts were a creative way of making sure we stay up-to-date in current innovations. I loved the speakers-- it was such a privilege to get to hear from experts in various industries and ask them questions. Finally, I really appreciated the no technology rule-- it made sure everyone was engaged and focused and not distracted by their computers. I really liked how we had to introduce ourselves, something we were passionate about, where we call home, etc. because I really got to know the students in my class.

response_text: Amazing course whether you are pursuing a career in product management or not. Career-focused courses are rare at Duke, and I feel like this course is an exceptional intro to giving students all means possible to begin a career in product management. A lot of the skills a product manager needs apply to many other fields, so this is a great course to take to help start your career.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned how to conduct ethnography on an in-depth level, learned more about how to understand positionality as an ethnographer/anthropologist, became more familiar with how anthropologists view issues

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: learned how to structure ethnographic research, how to approach interviewing, and how to organize data.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned specific interpersonal and research skills for ethnographic research. I learned how to code field notes to pull out important recurring themes and analyze those themes. I learned how to do more narrative ethnographic writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to write an ethnography 
2. How to do fieldwork 
3. How to write memos and code fieldwork

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write an ethnography in its full extent, how to code field notes, and overall gained a better understanding of the general foundation of cultural anthropology writing and how it has shifted since the inception of the filed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course is a perfect blueprint to writing an ethnography, and not only that, but study its core components, why its relevant in todays anthropology field, and where it can be applied in everyday/worldly scenarios. This course taught several skills sets, research related, finding the right methods for you / your project, and helpful writing tips, not just for ethnographies but research related in general (very helpful for a senior thesis).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was different than all the other anthropology courses. Instead of just learning about a topic or learning about anthropology you get to actually do it! I learned how to operate in the field as well as conduct interviews. This skills are valuable beyond anthropological research because it teaches you to be able to enter a space and be curious about it and how to interact to with those in it to learn more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct the foundational research methods in cul Anth: taking field notes, holding interviews, and performing content analysis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the general flow/structure of the class--we started the beginning by learning generally/broad structure about what fieldwork/ethnography is, then we narrowed the scope of our focus as we worked through the project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: lots of opportunities to work in class and to work through individual ideas with her and the peers which was very helpful when formulating my project idea, the boundaries of my research, research methods, and finally paper organization.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that giving us plenty of time to work on this semester-long project allowed us to really dig deep and learn anthropological methods through experience. I liked the structure of the class, with helpful readings in the beginning and then time to work on and discuss our projects, and the workshops were particularly helpful. Not only is it good to get commentary on my work, but it was also helpful to read other people's work to see how they were structuring or going about things.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I would keep...
1. the writing of an entire ethnography over the semester (really helps to turn concepts into things that are tried)
2. spending some class days doing work together (really forced me to revise certain aspects)
3. having sporadic assignments due (I liked being forced to use concepts I wouldn't have otherwise)
4. individual professor feedback

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was one of the best I have taken at Duke, to be completely honest. I learned the psychological underpinnings of the entire advertising/marketing industries, specifically about how brands can become living entities in the world that change with, and appeal to, consumers basic human emotions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how companies are often defined by their ability to build a brand and how the only thing that differentiates most companies is their brand. I learned how brands can improve their marketing and advertisements. I also learned how to engage the customer and build a brand that resonates with their emotions. I also discovered how most of human decision-making is subconscious. Having empathy for others can allow us to be more persuasive and form stronger connections with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course reshaped how I think about brand strategy. I learned to identify and leverage emotional territories, enabling me to craft brand narratives that connect authentically with audiences. The 10-second customer journey framework taught me to distill complex experiences into clear, impactful moments, enhancing strategic clarity. Additionally, adopting brand system thinking allowed me to see brands as interconnected ecosystems, where every element—from messaging to customer touchpoints—works cohesively. These insights have not only sharpened my strategic skills but also fostered a more empathetic approach to brand building.

response_text: This class was consistently intellectually stimulating because it bridged the emotional and rational sides of brand experience — a balance that is rare and extremely powerful. Learning how brands embed themselves into customers’ lives, not just their minds, reshaped the way I think about strategy. To elevate it even further, encouraging even more real-time case analysis (breaking down brand moves happening right now) could make the material feel even more immediate and electric.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class if you want to learn not just how brands grow, but why they matter. response_text: Take it! The first month or so is all accounting and valuation which can be pretty dull (at least for me), but Kathie explained why these skills are useful. The other content in the course is more what you would expect from an entrepreneurship class. You still learn a lot even without being burdened with tons of homework.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
- Most of the assignments are long group assignments that require everyone's availability which is almost next to impossible so it's hard to do good at any of the assignments.
- You will most likely get restless since most of the 2.5-hour lectures are non-interactive.
- There is no outside help in this course since the challenge is to deduce everything we don't know. If you have a doubt and email the TAs, they will say "We expect you to attempt this by yourself and provide 0 help". The TAs are also more just graders that I'm not sure have the expertise to be assessing us on a relative scale. It feels like they are hearing about the case studies with us. Not good.
- FUQUA IS FAR. You need to be here at 1:40 or whatever the starting time is otherwise it'll affect your grade. Doesn't make sense. Being 15 seconds late can't take off a percent of your grade.
- There are readings (need to pay $120) but she does not ask us directly to talk about it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked our podcast episodes that we were assigned to listen to, and the videos we were told to create to show that we listened. It was a great excuse to listen to some really interesting podcasts that I already wanted to listen to, and the video submissions were fun to do. This class was a rare example of a teacher adapting the curriculum and delivery to more technologically savvy classroom and the usage of video content, generative AI, and showed a willingness to adapt the course curriculum. I particularly liked the fact that one of our first assignments, which was to encourage another group of people to do their assignment, came out of the professor unsuccessfully trying to get students to do that very same assignment. And instead of having the hubris to continue on and blame the students, he was able to, much like a product, change it and its purpose. Very meta and in line with all these entrepreneurial values that we talk about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Design Thinking Process: Learned the structured phases of design thinking, including customer empathizing, opportunity definition, and solution ideation. Gained practical experience conducting stakeholder interviews and mapping value chains, which deepened the understanding of user-centered design.
Triple Bottom Line Analysis: Developed skills in evaluating business opportunities for their environmental, social, and economic impacts. This insight emphasized the importance of sustainability in innovation.
Entrepreneurship and Business Modeling: Acquired knowledge about creating business models, conducting market research, and pitching climate-tech ideas. This hands-on approach built confidence in entrepreneurial thinking and decision-making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The main tangible I developed during this course is how to navigate "tough" entrepreneurial situations within the context of a team. 
(1) Communication skills - the ability to share, critique, and build upon others' ideas
(2) Discerning value from conversations - the ability to have a conversation with someone who may only tangentially relate to your project, but connect their expertise to the overarching mission of your project
(3) Storytelling - how to get someone to care about what you are doing, the "why" aspect of a startup

- I think this class could have given students more room, time, and space to innovate and problem solve on their own and in a less set-in-stone time frame
- It might be more suitable for undergraduates or those very early in their careers.  For anyone who has had some professional experience, it can feel pretty stifling or taking a step back in terms of professional seriousness or rigor.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
What made this class stimulating:
The real-world feel of the class was something I had been craving out of school my whole life. You can't look up the answers to this class on Chegg! You have to look in the real world! This was incredibly an incredibly stimulating aspect.How could it be more intellectually stimulating:
More team building / alignment exercises / time-spent agreeing on what the project will look like. To be fair, this may be the fault of our Team Charter. However, I believe that that assignment could have been so much more than filling out the Team Charter template that the professors provided. We didn't realy talk about a way to come up with ideas and build them out. We didn't talk about how we were going to implement science and engineering into the course's assignments. If we had, there would have been more opportunity for intellectual stimulation.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Many assignments, especially those part of the business wayfinder, helped me think in new ways and challenge my assumptions. They were intellectually stimulating. However, they could've been better with some more time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to do a lot of work, but also have a lot of fun.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course has such amazing potential, though it is not quite refined yet. It needs to iterate before its vision is realized. Temper your expectations.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is time-consuming and emotionally taxing. We often find ourselves confused and frustrated as to why we're doing an assignment at this time because we haven't laid the groundwork for it (e.g., we're asked to do an assignment that assumes a solution when we haven't done enough research to understand the problem and ideate a solution).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think the student will get out what they put into this course. A lot of this course involves individualized student learning and outreach which takes on individual effort.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course, work in field is interesting and contribute to your development

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate is a hands-on, interdisciplinary course where you’ll tackle real-world climate challenges through design thinking and collaboration with industry professionals. You’ll gain valuable skills in sustainability, business modeling, and project management while creating and pitching impactful solutions. The workload is significant but rewarding, and the experience looks great on a resume. If you’re passionate about climate innovation and ready to learn by doing, this course is a fantastic opportunity!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate I focuses on understanding the market, interviewing stakeholders, and conducting SWOT analyses, all of which are essential for any business. If you're only interested in building cool technical devices, this class may not be the best fit for you. However, if you want to create something meaningful from scratch—designing a product that addresses a user's pain point—then this is the perfect class for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are no design elements in this course. It is a marketing/entrepreneurship course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're interested in business, climate change, and engineering (design thinking), you should take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Understand that while the projects you are working on are interesting, a lot of them are basically just filling a gap for an existing business or laying the groundwork for a potential nonprofit/business.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Only take this course if you are passionate about the topics. It will be more challenging and potentially detrimental to your team if you are not.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: - A crash course/simulation of developing a product, but not reflective of how things work in the "real world" or what it takes to develop a successful product; it will, however, give people a rough sense of the basics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are wondering "what content will be taught to me in this course" the answer is entrepreneurship 101. If you are looking to learn about a specific clean technology, whether it be related to renewable energy, infrastructure adaptation, sustainable materials, or sustainable business, it will not be taught to you. Further if you would like to apply engineering design, mechanical/electrical/chemical/computer engineering concepts, or any other area of academia, you will have to seek it out yourself. These realities, however, do reflect the real world. Just know what to expect.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While the course teaches you a lot of things in a short time, and helps you learn new skills, it is a lot of work. We are students at the end of the day, so we are juggling many other things besides this course. Be mindful of the time commitment and only take this course when your other work is less intense. Or if you are extremely passionate about one of the projects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think reading Disciplined Entrepreneurship was a great way to learn about how to do market research. Another valuable skill I learned from this course is conducting stakeholder interviews. I learned about what e-methane was - I had no idea what e-methane was or what the market for it was prior to taking this course. I also learned how to conduct a SWOT market analysis which I had not learned before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Creative thinking
Communication
Team work

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Design Thinking Process: Learned the structured phases of design thinking, including customer empathizing, opportunity definition, and solution ideation. Gained practical experience conducting stakeholder interviews and mapping value chains, which deepened the understanding of user-centered design.
Triple Bottom Line Analysis: Developed skills in evaluating business opportunities for their environmental, social, and economic impacts. This insight emphasized the importance of sustainability in innovation.
Entrepreneurship and Business Modeling: Acquired knowledge about creating business models, conducting market research, and pitching climate-tech ideas. This hands-on approach built confidence in entrepreneurial thinking and decision-making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Design thinking (Stakeholder Interview, impact-effort map, quantifying impact)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Puffery in marketing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: It's my first time in a business-related class, so I learned lots of new things in class, such as defining markets and costumes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, Innovative thinking, Industry research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct stakeholder interviews, how to pivot from idea to idea, and the difficult roadblocks that inevitably occur when turning a business into a reality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many skills in entrepreneurship such as: how to conduct market research/market segmentation, how to conduct empathy interviews to understand stakeholder perspectives, and how design thinking can strengthen the process of trying to upscale a startup.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Technology developments that Duke and its partners are working on, as well as the climate technology ecosystem in Durham/NC.
- "Lean startup"-esque methods, such as beachhead markets and SWOT analysis
- Technical understanding of the climate challenge we tackled.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The main tangible I developed during this course is how to navigate "tough" entrepreneurial situations within the context of a team. 
(1) Communication skills - the ability to share, critique, and build upon others' ideas
(2) Discerning value from conversations - the ability to have a conversation with someone who may only tangentially relate to your project, but connect their expertise to the overarching mission of your project
(3) Storytelling - how to get someone to care about what you are doing, the "why" aspect of a startup

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Understanding the process of converting idea into product. 
Creating a startup doesn't necessarily mean that innovator may have all the information and that it's okay
Market analysis and research

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the nature of group work, and I think it would be beneficial to keep group work as this class moves forward.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is an experiential learning course in that the goal of the course is to try to build out a climate tech startup. I felt sometimes the course structure(assignments, quizes, etc.) got in the way of the true goal. Intstructors were more focused on assignments and assessing the work we did than working WITH teams to guide and help development. I think there should be more collaboration going on between groups and instructors.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I very much enjoyed the design thinking workshop by the external consultant. I wish the class was more strongly informed by design thinking methodology rather than disciplined entrepreneurship.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the structure of the course because the assignments were all relevant to our learning for the course and for our advancing our potential business. I think we should have had lectures that focused more on how to conduct stakeholder interviews and providing a better structure prior to giving us the client list.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Constant support from instructors
Good theory accompanied with practise

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Instructor Support: The instructors provided clear guidance, responsive feedback, and encouraged collaboration. The availability of office hours and flexible scheduling supported deeper engagement.
Interdisciplinary Approach: Collaboration between students from different academic backgrounds enhanced problem-solving and creative thinking.
Project-Based Learning: The hands-on structure of the course, with real-world challenges and industry collaboration, made learning immersive and relevant.
Teamwork Emphasis: Group projects encouraged the development of teamwork and project management skills.

The main tangible I developed during this course is how to navigate "tough" entrepreneurial situations within the context of a team. 
(1) Communication skills - the ability to share, critique, and build upon others' ideas
(2) Discerning value from conversations - the ability to have a conversation with someone who may only tangentially relate to your project, but connect their expertise to the overarching mission of your project
(3) Storytelling - how to get someone to care about what you are doing, the "why" aspect of a startup

response_text:

Market analysis and research

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is an experiential learning course in that the goal of the course is to try to build out a climate tech startup. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
What made this class stimulating:
The real-world feel of the class was something I had been craving out of school my whole life. You can't look up the answers to this class on Chegg! You have to look in the real world! This was incredibly an incredibly stimulating aspect.How could it be more intellectually stimulating:
More team building / alignment exercises / time-spent agreeing on what the project will look like. To be fair, this may be the fault of our Team Charter. However, I believe that that assignment could have been so much more than filling out the Team Charter template that the professors provided. We didn't realy talk about a way to come up with ideas and build them out. We didn't talk about how we were going to implement science and engineering into the course's assignments. If we had, there would have been more opportunity for intellectual stimulation.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate is a hands-on, interdisciplinary course where you’ll tackle real-world climate challenges through design thinking and collaboration with industry professionals. You’ll gain valuable skills in sustainability, business modeling, and project management while creating and pitching impactful solutions. The workload is significant but rewarding, and the experience looks great on a resume. If you’re passionate about climate innovation and ready to learn by doing, this course is a fantastic opportunity!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Design Climate I focuses on understanding the market, interviewing stakeholders, and conducting SWOT analyses, all of which are essential for any business. If you're only interested in building cool technical devices, this class may not be the best fit for you. However, if you want to create something meaningful from scratch—designing a product that addresses a user's pain point—then this is the perfect class for you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are no design elements in this course. It is a marketing/entrepreneurship course.

response_text: If you're interested in business, climate change, and engineering (design thinking), you should take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: - A crash course/simulation of developing a product, but not reflective of how things work in the "real world" or what it takes to develop a successful product; it will, however, give people a rough sense of the basics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are wondering "what content will be taught to me in this course" the answer is entrepreneurship 101. If you are looking to learn about a specific clean technology, whether it be related to renewable energy, infrastructure adaptation, sustainable materials, or sustainable business, it will not be taught to you. Further if you would like to apply engineering design, mechanical/electrical/chemical/computer engineering concepts, or any other area of academia, you will have to seek it out yourself. These realities, however, do reflect the real world. Just know what to expect.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While the course teaches you a lot of things in a short time, and helps you learn new skills, it is a lot of work. We are students at the end of the day, so we are juggling many other things besides this course. Be mindful of the time commitment and only take this course when your other work is less intense. Or if you are extremely passionate about one of the projects.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor is a great guy and clearly passionate about Climate Tech, but so many things about this course were so bad. It was unstructured, the assignments felt random, there was no classroom engagement, there was no attempt to make sure everyone had a baseline knowledge of what was talked about, it was guest speakers speaking about their life and questions being asked by the same seven people because no one else knew what was going on. Oh and the students were not able to reach out to the professor. I directly emailed him multiple times and never got a response back. Students are forced to communicate directly with the TAs and have them be messengers to the professor. If I could I would restructure the course from the group up or not even teach it if the the changes are not made.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor and course structure were extremely engaging. Dr. Wedding is an outstanding teacher -- he was approachable, relatable, and extremely interesting. The format of the course, which combined lectures and ample venture capital and founder speakers, allowed me to both learn about climate tech startups and VC and see applications in the real world. Through conversations with different guest speakers, I gained an understanding of the unique perspectives, challenges, and goals of climate tech professionals. In future years, I would keep the combination of guest speakers and lectures. I appreciated the Canvas resources and professional development primers. As an undergraduate student, I felt like I learned a lot from the questions and experiences of the graduate students in the class. Finally, I found the readings and assignments extremely relevant, current and informative without being overwhelming or feeling like busy work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think there was lots of issues with the course, and I honestly didn't feel like I learnt anything more than what could have been said within 2 hours. A lot of the concepts that were stated in the syllabus was not covered at all, which was very disappointing. We kept going back to the same concepts week after week with nothing much added to these concepts, and many time going to class felt like a waste of time. There was also a lot of time during the classes where we had the opportunity to do group work, however I felt like all these sessions could have been done offline outside of class, especially considering how most of the syllabus was not actually covered. There was also an entire component about using a new AI tool that some people at Duke have developed, but I did not see how any of these could have been applied to what we are doing effectively. I expected that the class would teach me concepts and ideas to bring discoveries from the lab into translation, but it felt like a very generic business class, that skimmed through a lot of topics.

response_text: There was a lot of open debate/conversation. Ideas and assumptions were constantly challenged and most everyone was participating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that the "lessons" that Michelle and Alexis gave were very high level overviews of some basic concepts taught in business school, but did not go into anywhere near enough detail to be helpful. I think that some more activities around applying these concepts, or more detailed lessons could have been helpful. Alternatively, perhaps a short reading could be provided prior to lessons so that the class could all get to at least a baseline understanding prior to the class discussions. This could be more helpful for people who were less familiar, and could then allow for a richer discussion for people who were already familiar and wanted to try to take their learning and application to the next level.As noted above, I also think it would have been more interesting and helpful to meet the founders at the beginning of the course as well, and give us more context and more to think about/ consider throughout the term, reducing the time of the learning curve, and allowing for more time for critical thinking and analysis.

Sometimes in a team, only one person does it while the others do other aspects of the project, so some of us miss out on some skills which other get.
