question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I felt that the course focused on non-tangible items like "finding a Hero" in your customer which was a storied way of defining your target customer. We also learned the proper ratios of ethos, logos, and pathos depending on what type of story we were attempting to deliver for what medium. For example, a DoorDash CEO delivering a promotional campaign for Y Combinator looks a lot different than an activist giving a Ted Talk even if their key delivery points were centered around how they grew their passions into a sustainable business. Last thing was the Five C's: CHARACTER, CONTEXT, CONFLICT, CLIMAX, and CLOSURE. It's an easy arc to follow on how to outline your story and ensure it paints a holistic picture of your narrative.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I took great notes during this class (quotes, theories, discussions, etc) and it inspired me in new ways (ways my brain doesn't always think on the day-to-day). 
- I learned what Narrative Design and design thinking is (it sounds silly - but it's true!). I love that design thinking is human-centric, iterative, and a non-linear way of working. 
- I learned about starting with you "why" and talking about what you believe, not what you do.
- I learned that great stories happen to those who can tell them - and I have seen this throughout my life now that I have written it down in words, it is so true. There have been times where people in my life tell great stories (about things that I was present for) and they make the story sound way better than it actually was in person!

The mix of in class activities, videos, games and lecture was great!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The Narrative Design course at Duke’s Fuqua School of Business provided a highly engaging and interactive learning environment that fostered creativity and critical thinking. Several key aspects of the course structure and instructional methods significantly enhanced my learning experience:
1. Case-Based Learning & Real-World Applications – The use of case studies and real-world examples helped bridge the gap between theory and practice. Analyzing successful brand narratives and marketing strategies provided practical insights that I could immediately apply.2. Workshop-Style Discussions & Peer Feedback – The course encouraged open discussions and collaborative storytelling exercises. Receiving constructive feedback from both peers and the instructor refined my ability to craft compelling narratives and tailor messages for different audiences.3. Hands-On Storytelling Projects – The emphasis on experiential learning through projects made the course especially impactful. Developing, iterating, and presenting narratives in various formats reinforced key concepts and improved my confidence in strategic storytelling.I would highly recommend keeping these interactive and application-driven elements for future iterations of the course, as they create an immersive and dynamic learning experience.

response_text:
The Narrative Design course was intellectually stimulating due to its emphasis on real-world applications, interactive discussions, and creative problem-solving. Several elements contributed to its engaging nature:
1. Hands-On Storytelling Exercises – The opportunity to craft, refine, and present narratives made learning immersive and thought-provoking. Applying storytelling techniques to business scenarios enhanced both strategic thinking and creativity.2. Dynamic Class Discussions – Engaging in discussions about case studies and analyzing successful brand narratives provided diverse perspectives, encouraging critical thinking about the role of storytelling in business.To make the course even more intellectually stimulating, a few enhancements could be considered:
1. Challenging Real-World Case Competitions – Incorporating live case challenges where students develop and pitch a marketing or brand narrative to real companies could elevate engagement and provide valuable practical experience.2. Advanced Storytelling Techniques – Introducing more nuanced elements of storytelling, such as psychological triggers, behavioral science principles, or cross-cultural narrative strategies, could deepen understanding and push students to think more strategically.3. Greater Use of Multimedia & Technology – Exploring how digital storytelling tools (like AI-driven content generation, interactive storytelling, or data visualization) can enhance narratives could make the course even more future-focused and relevant.These additions would further challenge students, encourage innovation, and provide a richer, more intellectually stimulating learning experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
If you’re considering taking Narrative Design at Duke’s Fuqua School of Business, I highly recommend it! This course offers a deep dive into the power of storytelling and its critical role in marketing, branding, and business strategy. You’ll learn how to craft compelling narratives that resonate with different audiences, making it an essential skill for anyone interested in product management, marketing, consulting, or entrepreneurship.
The class is highly interactive, with engaging discussions, case studies, and hands-on storytelling exercises that challenge you to think creatively and strategically. You’ll also get valuable peer and instructor feedback to refine your communication skills.
If you enjoy analyzing brand strategies, developing impactful messaging, and using storytelling as a business tool, this course will be both intellectually stimulating and highly practical. Be ready to participate, experiment, and push your creative boundaries.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moyle created an incredibly supportive and entrepreneurial environment. His real-world experience as a founder and investor made every class insightful and relevant. The structure of the course—particularly the emphasis on rapid iteration, direct feedback, and weekly venture progress updates—kept us focused and accountable. The “Lean Canvas” and milestone-based structure were especially effective in helping us think practically and critically. I would strongly recommend keeping the one-on-one office hours, pitch workshops, and investor panels—each of these provided hands-on mentorship that was crucial to our growth.

IE company culture, networking strategy, and fundamental decision making on core principles and practices. I also gained exposure to business fundamentals that I haven't been exposed to before, finance accounting, negotiating, and fundraising strategies. Lastly, this course helped me gain a greater appreciation for what it takes to be an entrepreneur, sometimes it's not about how great the idea/product is, but about the team driving it forward.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is designed for those with graduate students with high technical expertise. However, there were nuggets of value for me by taking this course and so even with someone who has experience or listens to Freakanomics religiously, I would still recommend it. Plus, having interactions with other graduate students to get their perspectives on familiar topics was valuable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about public policy which was something I hadn't focused on here at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about what arts policy was, from the history of it to how it relates to my everyday life. I also learned great project-based skills like time management and communication. Furthermore, I learned how to write a policy brief, which is something I didn't know how to do before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical analysis of policies and institutions - i.e. considering how institutions are created and situated, and how this impacts the people attracted to this institution and how that institution is perceived

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to build knowledge in U.S. public policy, art and the intersection of both in a very engaging and practical way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of subtle, overlooked concepts. Creative placemaking, the interplay of public/private/non-profit institutions, and this is the biggest thing: a greater appreciation of arts institutions & events around me. Before this class, I really didn't look to go to museums or art exhibits or dance performances. However, my positive experiences with these aforementioned things have motivated me to go to more events around campus and Durham. I think this is most notable with the performances in Page Auditorium. I will also say this course has helped me network/ reach out when working with my community partner. This was especially relevant when I wanted to include an extra component in the project and I had to gather the resources/data from different teams in the organization and outside.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Understanding of public arts policy decision-making

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about what exactly is arts policy, various cultural institutions and its issues, leadership and value in the arts, cultural equity (audience and access, heritage and repatriation), creative placemaking, and creative economies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We reviewed case studies in arts leadership, visited local cultural organizations, and discussed the challenges facing the arts today. A central component of the course was the extended engagement with a community partner, so we developed our collaborative skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about art in a different and new context. I also learned professional skills through the service learning aspect of the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about cultural and arts policies, and how we can observe the phenomenons of these policies in real life. I gained insight on the impacts of cultural and arts policy, and how each action affects the communities around us.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned more about all different aspects of art policy
2. Learned how the arts directly spur economic activity
3. How to collaborate professionally in a workplace

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Specifically I learned how to analysis and interpret arts policy in the real world today and apply my leadership knowledge in unique ways to make a difference both in Durham and my local community here at Duke. I learned how to critically engage with peers about arts policy and discuss with them. Lastly, I learned how to work with community partners to ensure long-term success.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Nurkin was incredibly engaged and kind to his students!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course was one of my favorites so far at duke. Professor Nurkin is extremely engaging, and he makes learning fun! I had no prior knowledge of arts policy, yet he managed to keep me engaged the whole time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the small group discussions, and community building class excursions helped me feel comfortable and excited to learn and engage with the material

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I greatly appreciated how the course began with establishing a solid theoretical framework, which we then continuously applied to practical scenarios. The instructor's engaging approach, thoughtful questioning, and attentive listening fostered a dynamic and inclusive learning environment.​

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The absolute free-for-all structure of the discussions really helped me open up. I was never afraid to share my opinion, instead maybe I was more hesitant by ruminating and tweaking how I was going to say an idea. It also helped a very natural dialogue that was insightful. This is very dependent on the people in the class, though. I know there were 6-7 key yappers, but in a class with more shy people or only a few key people speaking, it would be much more anxious/forced.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Class visits and excursions

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is probably the most impactful class I have taken at Duke because I learned and experienced so much. We were put into group projects to help with a specific arts organization, where we gained so much insight on what it is like to help with arts administration as well as policy. We also went on multiple class excursions that allowed us to understand how the audience interacts with the art institutions, as well as our experience with it. Everything in this course- especially the content- was so meaningful and important for me to learn about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The site visits were interesting and varied! I enjoyed the collaboration with my group on the long-term project. Professor Nurkin was reasonable accessible and had helpful input.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The group service learning aspect of the course was what I learned the most from, which I enjoyed. The lectures were very informative and interesting, and I enjoyed the group work within the lectures. I also enjoyed the excursion aspect of the class. It gave us something tangible to relate what we learned in lecture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Class discussions could be very intellectually stimulating, though some discussions felt overly long and became unproductive. Something that could make this course more intellectually stimulating is if the class environment was more conducive to everyone/anyone being able to talk, as opposed to allowing some class conversations to be monopolized by a few people - i.e. efforts to bring in other voices too

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was intellectually stimulating due to its thoughtful discussions that connected theoretical concepts to real-world policies. Engaging in group work at the end of each session allowed us to apply theories in practical contexts, enhancing our understanding and retention.​

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The biggest stimulating factor were the fieldtrips & the semester long project. They were more dynamic and allowed us to incorporate a lot of skills we personally had. It gave us an organization or community to reach out to, which helped. I think tying the fieldtrips back to the concepts we learned was enlightening. This was most seen in the writing assignments, such as the discussion posts. There was a lot of critical thinking and realization that "oh yeah, this particular institution shows a concept we highlighted in class" or "I did not even realize this institution probably had to mull over their economics & that this affected their policy." I think the final paper was kind of shoved in there at the end, but I much prefer that over any final exam.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More stimulating if we talked more about specific examples closer to us

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very engaging! It was especially interesting for me because I wanted to learn everything about Arts Policy, and I wanted to gain as much information in this field as possible. I think the only caveat was that the class felt a little long sometimes, since it was over 2 hours, but we had breaks in the middle of it. However, mostly the whole class was very stimulating and engaging.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I would love more emphasis on excursions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is perfect for students interested in exploring public policy and the arts, even without prior experience. response_text: Go to as many excursions as possible. Don't feel constrained by your project. If its not up to your liking, ask your community partner to see if you could incorporate more into it. This was my dilemma.

response_text: Definitely take it!
